raw.author: Paul Rée
contexts: the whole book as a sort of superior Realism. As a matter of fact it contradicts five or six of my friend's utterances: only read the introduction to The Genealogy of Morals on this question.—The passage above referred to reads: "What, after all, is the principal axiom to which the boldest and coldest thinker, the author of the book 'On the Origin of Moral Sensations' (read Nietzsche, the first Immoralist), 'has attained by means of his incisive and decisive analysis of human actions?"
commentaries: The author mentions his friend Paul Rée as a thinker whose ideas are referenced and contrasted, noting that his own work contradicts several of Rée's utterances.

raw.author: Schopenhauer

raw.title: Thus Spake Zarathustra: A Book for All and None
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
contexts: "THUS SPAKE ZARATHUSTRA: A BOOK FOR ALL AND NONE" 1 I now wish to relate the history of Zarathustra.
If you should require a formula for a destiny of this kind that has taken human form, you will find it in my Zarathustra.

"And he who would be a creator in good and evil—verily, he must first be a destroyer, and break values into pieces.
"Thus the greatest evil belongeth unto the greatest good: but this is the creative good."

Zarathustra says: "Good men never speak the truth.
False shores and false harbours were ye taught by the good.
In the lies of the good were ye born and bred.
Through the good everything hath become false and crooked from the roots."

"The good—they cannot create; they are ever the beginning of the end.
"They crucify him who writeth new values on new tables; they sacrifice unto themselves the future; they crucify the whole future of humanity!
"The good—they are ever the beginning of the end."
"And whatever harm the slanderers of the world may do, the harm of the good is the most calamitous of all harm."
commentaries: The author introduces his own book, Zarathustra, and proceeds to detail its conception and composition.
The author presents his own book 'Zarathustra' as the source of a formula for a destiny that has taken human form.
The author quotes directly from his book 'Zarathustra' to illustrate the concept of creation through destruction.
The author quotes from 'Zarathustra' to argue that good men are fundamentally dishonest and that their influence corrupts truth.
The author quotes from 'Zarathustra' to depict the good as destructive forces that oppose innovation and sacrifice the future.
The author quotes from 'Zarathustra' to claim that the harm caused by good people is the most disastrous.

goodreads_match.title_without_series: Thus Spake Zarathustra: A Book for All and None
goodreads_match.title: Thus Spake Zarathustra: A Book for All and None
goodreads_match.description: Thus Spoke Zarathustra (subtitled as A Book for All and None) chronicles the fictitious travels and speeches of Zarathustra, the founder of Zoroastrianism. While Nietzsche injects myriad ideas into the book, a few recurring themes stand out. The overman (Ubermensch), a self-mastered individual who has achieved his full power, is an almost omnipresent idea in Thus Spoke Zarathustra. Man as a race is merely a bridge between animals and the overman. Nietzsche also makes a point that the overman is not an end r...

raw.author: Buddha
contexts: This was fully grasped by that profound physiologist Buddha. His "religion," which it would be better to call a system of hygiene, in order to avoid confounding it with a creed so wretched as Christianity, depended for its effect upon the triumph over resentment: to make the soul free therefrom was considered the first step towards recovery. "Not through hostility is hostility put to flight; through friendship does hostility end": this stands at the beginning of Buddha's teaching—this is not a precept of morality, but of physiology.
commentaries: The author references Buddha's teachings as a system of hygiene that emphasizes overcoming resentment, interpreting it as a physiological principle rather than a moral one.

raw.author: Corneille
contexts: if my artist's taste endeavours to defend the names of Molière, Corneille, and Racine
commentaries: The author defends Corneille, along with Molière and Racine, against Shakespeare, indicating a preference for French classical drama.

raw.author: Hegel
contexts: all of whom were corrupted by German philosophy (Taine, for instance, by Hegel, whom he has to thank for his misunderstanding of great men and great periods).
Its attitude towards politics is one of indifference,—"un-German," as people would say to-day,—it smells offensively of Hegel;
commentaries: The author criticizes Hegel for corrupting French masters like Taine, leading to a misunderstanding of great men and periods.
The author notes that his book 'The Birth of Tragedy' has a philosophical scent or influence of Hegel.

raw.author: Shakespeare
contexts: against such a wild genius as Shakespeare
When I cast about me for my highest formula of Shakespeare, I find invariably but this one: that he conceived the type of Cæsar.
a Goethe or a Shakespeare would not for an instant have known how to take breath in this atmosphere of passion and of the heights
commentaries: The author contrasts Shakespeare's 'wild genius' with the French dramatists Molière, Corneille, and Racine.
The author identifies Shakespeare's conception of Caesar as his highest achievement, implying that only one who embodies such greatness can create it.
The author suggests that Shakespeare, along with Goethe, would be unable to endure the intense atmosphere of Zarathustra's world.

goodreads_match.title: The Gay Science
goodreads_match.description: Philosophical work by Friedrich Nietzsche, originally titled 'Die fröhliche Wissenschaft' (The Joyful Science), often translated as 'The Gay Science' or 'Joyful Wisdom'. It introduces the concept of 'God is dead' and contains Nietzsche's first use of the idea of eternal recurrence.

contexts: Is Hamlet understood? It is not doubt, but certitude that drives one mad....
commentaries: The author offers an interpretation of 'Hamlet', arguing that it is certainty, not doubt, that leads to madness, and links this to philosophical depth.

goodreads_match.title: Hamlet

raw.title: Faust
raw.author: Goethe
contexts: Words fail me, I have only a look, for those who dare to utter the name of Faust in the presence of Manfred.
commentaries: The author dismisses comparisons between 'Faust' and 'Manfred', suggesting 'Manfred' is superior and that mentioning 'Faust' in its context is audacious.

goodreads_match.title: Faust
goodreads_match.description: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's Faust is a tragic play in two parts: Faust. Der Tragodie erster Teil (translated as: Faust: The First Part of the Tragedy) and Faust. Der Tragodie zweiter Teil (Faust: The Second Part of the Tragedy). Although rarely staged in its entirety, it is the play with the largest audience numbers on German-language stages. Faust is Goethe's most famous work and considered by many to be one of the greatest works of German literature.

raw.title: The Genealogy of Morals

contexts: "THE GENEALOGY OF MORALS: A POLEMIC"
commentaries: The author describes the three essays of this work as curious, calculated to mystify, and revealing unpleasant truths about Christianity, conscience, and the ascetic ideal.

goodreads_match.title: The Genealogy of Morals
goodreads_match.description:
Written in response to a book on the origins of morality by his erstwhile friend Paul Ree, the three essays comprising The Genealogy of Morals-- all three advancing the critique of Christian morality set forth in Beyond Good and Evil-- are among Nietzsche's most sustained and cohesive work.
In the first essay -- starting from a linguistic analysis of words such as "good," "bad," and "evil" -- Nietzsche sets up a contrast between what he calls "master" morality and "slave" morality and shows how strength and...

raw.author: Plato
contexts: for his nose scents decomposition.
Plato made use of Socrates in the same way—that is to say, as a cipher for Plato.
commentaries: The author references Plato as a source of degenerate idealism, contrasting it with Dionysian philosophy, and suggests that understanding the Dionysian makes refuting Plato unnecessary.
The author cites Plato's use of Socrates as a literary device, comparing it to his own method of using Schopenhauer and Wagner as vehicles for his ideas.

raw.author: Wagner
contexts: I could never have survived my youth without Wagnerian music.
I have loved Wagner.
commentaries: The author credits Wagner's music as essential to his psychological survival during his youth, describing it as a counter-poison to German culture.
The author references Wagner as a personal and intellectual influence, acknowledging a complex relationship despite the critical stance taken in the work.

raw.author: Lord Bacon

raw.author: Carlyle
contexts: Other learned cattle have suspected me of Darwinism on account of this word: even the "hero cult" of that great unconscious and involuntary swindler, Carlyle,—a cult which I repudiated with such roguish malice,—was recognised in my doctrine.
commentaries: The author mentions Carlyle's 'hero cult' as something mistakenly associated with his own ideas, which he repudiates with malice.

raw.author: Goethe
contexts: Her brother, Krause, the Professor of Theology in Königsberg, was called to the post of General Superintendent at Weimar after Herder's death.
a Goethe or a Shakespeare would not for an instant have known how to take breath in this atmosphere of passion and of the heights
commentaries: The author references Herder in the context of his grandmother's social circle in Weimar, implying Herder's influence or presence as a figure of intellectual history.
The author suggests that Goethe, along with Shakespeare, would be unable to endure the intense atmosphere of Zarathustra's world.

raw.author: Socrates
contexts: All the morbid disturbances of the intellect, even that semi-stupor which accompanies fever, have, unto this day, remained completely unknown to me; and for my first information concerning their nature and frequency, I was obliged to have recourse to the learned works which have been compiled on the subject.

and, secondly, the comprehension of Socraticism—Socrates being presented for the first time as the instrument of Greek dissolution, as a typical decadent. "Reason" versus Instinct. "Reason" at any cost, as a dangerous, life-undermining force.
commentaries: The author references Socrates as a famous case of dialectic being a symptom of decadence, using him as an example within his argument about intellectual health.
The author references Socrates as a philosophical figure and his concept of 'Reason' as a decadent force.

raw.author: Horace
contexts: a reader such as I deserve, and one who reads me just as the good old philologists used to read their Horace.
commentaries: The author uses the reading of Horace by classical philologists as a benchmark for the kind of attentive, worthy reader his own works deserve.

raw.title: On the Origin of Moral Sensations
raw.author: Paul Rée
contexts: "What, after all, is the principal axiom to which the boldest and coldest thinker, the author of the book 'On the Origin of Moral Sensations' (read Nietzsche, the first Immoralist), 'has attained by means of his incisive and decisive analysis of human actions?"
commentaries: The author references Rée's book as part of a self-referential analysis, using it to illustrate the ideas of the 'first Immoralist' (himself) and the theory that there is no intelligible metaphysical world.

goodreads_match.title: Der Ursprung der moralischen Empfindungen
goodreads_match.description: A philosophical work by Paul Rée analyzing the psychological and historical origins of moral concepts, influential on Nietzsche's thinking.

raw.title: Beyond Good and Evil
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
contexts: BEYOND GOOD AND EVIL: "THE PRELUDE TO A PHILOSOPHY OF THE FUTURE"

I forbid, by the bye, any guessing as to whom I am describing in this passage. "The genius of the heart, as that great anchorite possesses it, the divine tempter and born Pied Piper of consciences, whose voice knows how to sink into the inmost depths of every soul, who neither utters a word nor casts a glance, in which some seductive motive or trick does not lie: a part of whose masterliness is that he understands the art of seeming—not what he is, but that which will place a fresh constraint upon his followers to press ever more closely upon him, to follow him ever more enthusiastically and whole-heartedly....
commentaries: The author presents this book as a criticism of modernity and a school for a noble, yea-saying type of gentleman, following the affirmative work of Zarathustra.
The author quotes a passage from his own book to illustrate his skill as a psychologist.

goodreads_match.title: Beyond Good and Evil: Prelude to a Philosophy of the Future
goodreads_match.description: A major philosophical work by Friedrich Nietzsche that expands upon ideas from Thus Spoke Zarathustra and critiques traditional morality, truth, and philosophy.

raw.title: Manfred

goodreads_match.title: Manfred
goodreads_match.description: Manfred, a Faustian noble, is tortured by guilt over the death of his beloved, Astarte. He uses his mastery of language and spell-casting to summon seven spirits, from whom he seeks forgetfulness. The spirits are unable to control the past and thus cannot grant Manfred's plea.

goodreads_match.title: The Birth of Tragedy
goodreads_match.description: In The Birth of TragedyNietzsche expounds on the origins of Greek tragedy and its relevance to the German culture of its time. He declares it to be the expression of a culture which has achieved a delicate but powerful balance between Dionysian insight into the chaos and suffering which underlies all existence and the discipline and clarity of rational Apollonian form. In order to promote a return to these values, Nietzsche critiques complacent rationalism of late nineteenth-century German culture and makes...
